paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine induce an interferon-rich tumor inflammatory state that increases sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint blockade?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Preclinical cohort of tumor-bearing mice treated with intratumoral mRNA vaccine plus anti-PD-L1 combination therapy, pooled across repeat experiments.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort (vaccine only / ICI only / vehicle)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched preclinical control cohorts including vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle control conditions, pooled across matched controls.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, analyzed by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subgroup of the retrospective metastatic cohort with prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination exposure.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subgroup of the retrospective metastatic cohort without prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination exposure.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, so residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across settings.
